title: Sri Lanka bond yields soar, 2031 bonds 15.42-pct  after money printing
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s bond yields soared at Friday’s auction with 73 billion rupees being raised, with 2031 bonds rising to 15.42 percent from 12.70 in an action on February 11, data from the debt office showed.
The debt office raised 30.4 billion rupees from 01.12.2022 bonds after offering 60 billion rupees.
The debt office raised 25 billion rupees from 01.08.2024 bonds at 14.41 percent after offering 25 billion rupees at 1.41 percent.
Another 17.6 billion rupees was raised from 15.06.2027 bonds after offering 35 billion rupees at 14.70 percent.
15.06.2027 bond were last sold at 11.92 percent on February 11.
Sri Lanka is in a currency and debt crisis after price controls were placed on bond auctions in 2020 and 2021 and large volumes of money was printed triggering balance of payments deficits.
When Sri Lanka’s central bank prints money to keep rates down, the resulting currency crisis pushes rates to very high levels and the currency peg breaks.

Analysts call the phenomenon ‘Rawlath ne kendath ne’ in reference to an traditional saying which says by trying to save two things the beard (interest rate) and the soup (exchange rate), ultimately both cannot be saved.
However similar strategies have been followed for 72 years in Sri Lanka since a Latin America style central bank was set up. (Colombo/Mar11/2022)
